en: After the Allied invasion of Normandy in June, 1944, the troops moved to liberate Paris in August of 1945. The Ardennes offensive, or the "Battle of the Bulge" was the last counter attack of the Germans in 1944. The 101st Airborne was involved in the attacks on Ardennes and Alsace in 1945 after the Operation Wacht Am Rhein failed and the Allies needed to re-secure the area. The photograph's caption "the Yanks are coming" may allude to the military vehicles traveling through the city pictured, and to the continued presence of American troops in France until the end of the war.
Era 8 - The Great Depression and World War II (1929-1945)

After the Allied invasion of Normandy in June, 1944, the troops moved to liberate Paris in August of 1945. The Ardennes offensive, or the "Battle of the Bulge" was the last counter attack of the Germans in 1944. The 101st Airborne was involved in the attacks on Ardennes and Alsace in 1945 after the Operation Wacht Am Rhein failed and the Allies needed to re-secure the area. The photograph's caption "the Yanks are coming" may allude to the military vehicles traveling through the city pictured, and to the continued presence of American troops in France until the end of the war.
University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
